body: The opposite is true too. If `actions :show` is set, the breadcrumb should not be link_tos.

Folks – part 1: 

https://github.com/stuffmc/active_admin/commit/0a11be803c6f5f701f19a3d437e0dbaa5a59f4b3

This allow to see that we're in Edit mode in the Breacrumb.

part 2:

https://github.com/stuffmc/active_admin/commit/74961b62203b60360e95235ecef277f367a60d86

This checks (in a very non optimised way, but one get the idea and this is why it's in an _experimental_ branch) that the app has a route for this path — otherwise doesn't make it an hyperlink.

Only tiny problem with this commit: I broke `breadcrumbs_spec` because it awaits a link_to always and I sometime return just a string. Fixing those tests would be trivial though.

+1

i only have an edit page, so i need to activate the show method and redirect to edit :/

+1

Any chance we see this done? It's annoying to have admin files full of redirect actions.
I need this feature too. Related to #2181
Yep, same here guys ! I disabled the show action, but the breadcrumb still links to it... Keep up the good work guys.

Ok people, just a quick fix for those in need, let's say you not using the show method:

``` ruby
controller do   
   def show
      redirect_to action: 'index'
   end
end
```
This has been resolved by ae862fda64b2e44f676080bd7a5cb87dabbf449a. Please let me know if anything more needs to be done!
Can it also be included in the 0.6 branch?

I confirm ! Works great now, no linking to show action if it has been disabled. For those still not seeing the change, please use this line in your Gemfile, to track master:

``` ruby
gem 'activeadmin', github: 'gregbell/active_admin', branch: 'master'
```

Thanks Sean for the great work !

I'm using `active_admin` gem in few rails 3.2 applications, and I can't upgrade them yet to rails 4 to use `master` branch. So may be it will be possible to cherry-pick that patch to 0.6.x branch somewhere soon?

I’m not sure man, the devs will tell you, but what you could do for now is unpack your 0.6.X gem, make the change, rebuild it, and install it locally… But of course, doing that you’ll miss on future 0.6.X updates… Just a thought. Good luck !

A better way would be to fork your own version of ActiveAdmin, create a new branch off of 0.6.x, and cherry-pick ae862fd into your branch, and link to that version in your `Gemfile`. That way you can always keep your branch up to date with master - just fetch, merge, and rebase.

``` ruby
gem 'activeadmin', github: 'dmitry/active_admin', branch: '0-6-stable-dmitry'
```

``` sh
$ git fetch upstream
$ git merge upstream/0-6-stable
$ git checkout 0-6-stable-dmitry
$ git rebase 0-6-stable
```
Or I can just do a pull-request, if it will be merged into a 0.6?!
Also legitimate (and better). As long as the tests pass and there aren't any conflicts I don't see why it wouldn't get pulled in.
You can always submit a pull-request using the solution posted above, and just use your own branch until it is pulled into master.

Thank you guys!

This issue can be already included in the README as a reference how to be when you need some feature, but your working branch is out of mainstream. :smiley:
I just cherry-picked that commit onto the `0-6-stable` branch, to be included in 0.6.4.
Ah, the top of the commit message got accidentally removed. I force-pushed b41450a52c096af8794df0eb0c09bd1d4bf1cdf1 to fix that.

Thanks! Found one issue. I'm using `to_param` method in my model, so the URI to resource is not the sql numeric id or mongo - id: https://github.com/gregbell/active_admin/blob/b41450a52c096af8794df0eb0c09bd1d4bf1cdf1/lib/active_admin/view_helpers/breadcrumb_helper.rb#L16

This line should be moved out of the code.

``` ruby
          config = active_admin_config
          if part =~ /\A(\d+|[a-f0-9]{24})\z/ && parts[index-1]
            parent = active_admin_config.belongs_to_config.try :target
            config = parent if parent && parent.resource_name.route_key == parts[index-1]
            name   = display_name config.find_resource part
          end
```

Don't have time to push the code and make a pull-request, but if nothing happens here, I will do.
